results.title: Celebrations
results.creator_credit: Maija Rove, Griffith University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Dragon’s tongue”.
Centred around various festivals, particularly the Spring festival or Chinese New Year, this program looks at the lion dance, the use of firecrackers weddings, birthdays and the Chinese national day. Vocabulary learnt is centred around time, with examples being, “How long?”, “time off”, “often”, “How many?”. Professor Colin Mackerras attends a wedding and explains how a wedding is celebrated, and some of the traditions associated with birthdays. The calligraphy section shows various characters for different festivals. There are dramatised sequences which show a family celebrating the Spring festival, and a birthday, and we also witness a performance of “Waltzing Matilda” in Chinese.

results.title: New directions
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Tuggelin Yourgrau and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 26 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
Philip Zimbardo surveys a range of leading American psychologists to discover where they see psychology heading. Psychologists consulted include cognitive psychologist, Howard Gardiner and pioneer behaviourist, B. F. Skinner, both of Harvard University; psycholinguist, Jean Berko-Gleason; social behaviourist, Steven Suonin; neuroscientist, Richard Thompson of UCLA; and F.W. Putnam-Niha, specialist in multiple personality disorders.

results.title: The Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Dragon’s tongue”.
This program looks at the Peking Opera genre of juggling and acrobatics. Vocabulary in this section is concerned with questions such as “Do you perform often?’ and “Is Peking Opera difficult to learn?” Other sections include a look at jade, the “Yang qin” ( a Chinese musical instrument), three short dramatisations and a calligraphy section on the character for skill and its derivatives. Presented by Colin MacKerras.

results.title: Leisure
results.creator_credit: Maija Rove and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Dragon’s tongue”.
In this second episode we are introduced to simple vocabulary associated with leisure activities and the phrases “Do you like?”, “What do you like?”, “How many times?” as well as vocabulary associated with weather and family members. The calligraphy section shows words which include “ball”, eg. “football”, “volleyball”, etc. The program concludes with two short dramatised situations “The TV addict” and “The Picnic” in which a Chinese couple are introduced to the joys of the Australian barbecue. In Mandarin and English.

results.title: Past, present and promise
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Tuggelin Yourgrau and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
In this first program Philip Zimbardo introduces us to the fascinating science of psychology, a science at the crossroads of a wide variety of subjects such as philosophy, anthropology, biochemistry and artificial intelligence. He outlines what psychologists do and some of the different approaches taken to the study of the brain, mind and behaviour, including a brief history of psychology.

results.title: Family and pets
results.creator_credit: Maija Rove, Griffith University and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Dragon’s tongue”.
This first episode introduces the phrases “What is your name?”, “How old are you?” and their answers, “This is”, “He is” and “She is” and words for family members and pets. At the same time we are shown the homes of two different families in Beijing, glimpses of children at school, a zoo visit and the pets the Chinese keep. We also have a brief introduction to calligraphy and how the modern pictograms have developed. Introduced by Colin McKerras. In Mandarin and English.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Maija Rove, Griffith University and Australian Broadcasting Corporation

results.title: Cognitive processes
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Tuggelin Yourgrau and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
Why have people always been able to link different elements and ideas into coherent relationships? It is our thoughts, our cognitive processes, that give meaning to everything. In this program, Philip Zimbardo examines the work of cognitive psychologists who study how people take in information, store it, transmit it and manipulate it, that is, exploring how we think and solve problems.

results.title: Dragon's tongue
results.creator_credit: Maija Rove, Asian Studies Council, Griffith University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: A series of lessons in the Chinese language intended for high school students who have studied Chinese for two years. Each lesson includes some simple vocabulary, calligraphy, brief dramatisations which utilise the vocabulary and short sections on life in modern China. Introduced by Colin McKerras.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Maija Rove, Asian Studies Council, Griffith University and ABC-TV (Australia)

results.title: Sex and gender
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Tuggelin Yourgrau and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 17 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
A person’s sex - male or female, is determined at birth, but gender - masculine or feminine, is largely a learned behaviour, determined by social and cultural expectations. This program examines the debate on how much of human behaviour is innate and determined biologically according to sex, and how much is the result of the individual’s cultural context.
